text:
I was going to say as a
part of my introduction that I am a very new
assistant professor.

So I still kind of-- when
I'm introducing myself, I have to remind myself to
say assistant professor rather

than PhD student. But Michael already did that. So that's great. So today, I'm really
excited to talk to you

all about Leveraging Social
Theories to Enhance Human-AI Interaction. Let me make that a little bit
more concrete to begin with.

So I leverage theories
about an understanding of how people
think, communicate,

and collaborate to design
effective and safe human-AI interaction.

I'll share more about this
as I answer three questions during this talk. What is an effective
human-AI partnership?

How can we make human-AI
interactions safe? And what can we do to enhance
human-AI interaction going

forward? So let's start with the
first question there. What is an effective
human-AI partnership?

Effectiveness to me is about
combining people and AI in a way that takes advantage
of what they're each good at.

So I'm going to give you a
very brief example of this for the setting of visual
question and asking.

So not a deep dive, just a quick
overview of what I mean here. So visual question asking starts
with a visually impaired user

sharing an image, along
with a query online and trying to get an answer
about what's in that image.

So some examples of this
are, what color is this, or what item is this?

Because they can't
see their environment, they're trying to get these
answers by asking them online. Now these questions
with these images

are fairly easy to
answer, especially with recent advances
in computer vision.

But things can get
tricky very quickly. Now visually impaired
users can't always see the environment that they're
taking a picture in, right?

So they can share potentially
sensitive content online. So, for example, someone might
ask, which medication is this?

And instead of just sharing
the medication packet, they can share a
prescription bottle with their name or
their address on it.

Or someone can share a random
image from their gallery with their face on it, and that
leaks information about them

online. So what do we do here? How do we prevent
visually impaired users

from sharing private
content online but also still be able to
get answers to their queries?

One way to think
about a solution is, can we obfuscate,
pre-process, the image in some way so it
hides this potentially sensitive

content? So, for example, if this
is your original image, can you obfuscate it to maintain
the context but not share

what's private? Now this task is really hard for
people or AI to do on their own.

AI doesn't always
understand what we mean when we say
private or sensitive. So it can't automatically
do this task.

And people aren't a very
reliable way of doing it either. In both cases, whether you
try to use people or AI

individually, you have to
share the original image with them, which defeats the
purpose of the task itself.

So to solve this problem in a
human-AI effective partnership way, we divided an
image into segments.

And then we had crowdworkers
look at one segment at a time. So instead of seeing
the full image, they just see a little segment.

Now people are really good at
understanding context that AI isn't. So when I see a nose
in that segment,

I can guess that that's probably
a face in the surrounding segments. And mark them, guess them
as sensitive as well, right?

And we used AI for this task to
optimize for a certain budget that users provided
and also making

real-time decisions around
which segments of these need to even be shown again
to different crowdworkers

to make a decision
about their sensitivity. So that's what I mean when
I say an effective human-AI

partnership. We started them
with small segments. And we progressively had them
label larger segments that

were already masked
to get to this image on the bottom left that was then
sent to third-party Q&A websites

to get answers to
people's queries. I've done this effective
partnership of people in AI

in different types of domains-- visual Q&A, workplace
settings, for data science.

And in all of these,
the question that comes up next for me,
personally, is, well, what

about real-world deployment? We're trying to build
these systems for research. But, ultimately,
we want to put them

in front of actual
users in the wild. And that's not quite as easy as
just taking the research system

and then making it
available to everyone. There's a lot of
additional considerations that we don't think of
when we're building them

There might be crowdworkers that
would work together on a forum and adversarially attack the
system to get all of the image

segments back from it, right? So there's things that
you can't anticipate. And now you might think, OK,
that's a hypothetical bad thing

that could happen. But there's a lot
of evidence of how, when human and AI systems
are deployed in the wild,

bad things can happen. Biases that we haven't
considered or harms that we don't think about can
come up in these settings.

So in my research,
this effectiveness is just one piece of it. There's this whole
conversation around safety

when you think about deploying
these systems in the real world. And in my research,
I try to bridge

that delta between innovation
and effective deployment in the real world by
thinking about safety.

And this includes two questions
about, first, understanding what's wrong, understanding
the incompatibilities that

are at play that cause harms
and biases in the wild, and then also trying to address
those incompatibilities.

And that's where I'm going to
talk about next with how do we make human-AI interaction safe.

But before I do that,
any questions so far? I'm happy to answer
clarifying questions as I go

and then leave big
questions for the end.

OK. So, luckily, I'm
not the only person trying to study how to make
human-AI interaction safe.

There is a major thrust of
research on interpretability and explainability,
with the idea being

to help people understand AI and
machine-learning systems that are deployed in the wild. And the assumption there
being, if we can help people

understand what these
AI and complex AI and machine-learning
systems are doing, then maybe we can stop potential
harms before they happen

or potential risks before
they are put in the systems. There are two major
approaches to this.

There are glass box models that
are inherently interpretable, where I'm very quickly able to
tell how a set of input features

leads to a predicted outcome. And then there are
black box models, where you can't really tell what
the machine-learning model is

doing. But the community has
developed post-hoc explainers for these models that
approximate their behavior

and so are able to give
you some idea of how a set of input features
leads to a predicted outcome.

With these approaches,
you can normally get three types
of visual outputs. So, say, you were
predicting income

based on demographic data. You could get a
local explanation. This tells you how a
single prediction was made.

So on the y-axis, here are
values of a single individual. And then you can see how they
shaped the final predicted class

of income. Here at 0, 0 just means
less than 50k income.

You can also get specific
feature explanations, which tell you how a
single feature affects

the predicted outcomes. So here you can see how age
impacts income across all data points in the data set.

And then if you do this for
all features being used, then you can get
a global ordering

of what the model considers
important overall, what it learns about the data
set, and all of its features.

And that's called a
global explanation. So these explanations
provide insight

into model behavior and AI
that we did not have before.

But the question that remains
is, does this work in practice? Do people who use
these systems, then,

are able to make
better decisions about the data and the model? And that was one
of the questions

that we wanted to tackle in
this project that we did. This was one of the
first human evaluations

of these tools in
practice, which was done with data scientists. Data scientists
because they have

some machine-learning
expertise already. They know the
machine-learning concepts we're talking about here.

So we started with nuanced
qualitative interviews to understand the challenges
that come up in the data science

pipeline. We followed this up with
synthesizing these challenges

into a data set and then
running contextual inquiries to understand if
people were able to use

interpretability tools to
resolve these challenges. And then we wanted to
quantify those findings.

So we conducted a
large scale survey to see if those findings
from our contextual inquiry held up at a large scale.

Unfortunately, what we found
was that interpretability alone does not work.

Rather, people
misuse and overtrust interpretability and
explainability tools. So less than 4% of 197 data
scientists in our study

could accurately describe what
these visual explanations could do or what they were
trying to tell us, right?

Most of them overestimated
the capabilities of interpretability tools. So here you can see on the
y-axis various different

capabilities of
interpretability tools. And we had asked
people to select all that apply to the tool that
they were using in the study.

Of these capabilities, only
the ones in these bounded boxes

were actual capabilities
of these tools at the time of the study. And as you can see, people
assigned a lot more value

in terms of capabilities
to these tools than was actually
possible at the time. And some of these are things
that are realistically not going

to be possible for a
long time, like automated detection of fairness issues. No tool is capable
of automatically

understanding all fairness
issues in a system. Most data scientists
gave our erroneous model

that we had shared with them
very high deployment scores. So they said, oh,
you could deploy this in a loan application
being used in the wild.

You could do this right now
with the data in the model that you have. Now, again, like I said, we
had synthesized some errors

in the data, right? So as a result, one of the
visuals that people saw was this.

So what we had done was
impute 10% of the age values in the data
set with the mean age.

As a result, around
that mean age of 38, 39, you see a huge spike
in the relationship

between age and income. So we had synthetically
introduced this error and several others.

And we were hoping that
after seeing these visuals with these errors, people would
say, well, this model is not

ready for deployment. But most of them gave it
a score of, on average, 5

on a scale of 0 to 7. So they thought it was ready. They came up with narratives
to justify this spike.

So one thing that a lot of
the participants in our study said, well, around
38 or 39 is when

you pay off all of your loans. So you're actually taking all
of your income home with you.

So the spike makes sense, right? So they came up with
these narratives to justify what was
being shown by the tool,

rather than using it as
an evaluative device. So interpretability,
as currently designed,

does not work. The solution that
is intended to help make human-AI systems safe for
deployment doesn't quite work.

Now, naturally, the next
question that comes to mind is, why? What's going on here?

And that was the question
that we wanted to ask as well. And again, we
wanted to study this

in a-- we wanted to not just
think of interpretability as a technical
solution but think

of what social human-centered
factors might be at play.

So we hypothesized
that the bounded nature of human rationality was
what was going on over here.

So there's the
cognitive framework called bounded rationality,
which essentially says that cognition is expensive.

So people apply
heuristics as shortcuts to make their decision
making easier. Our brain has two systems--

system 1 and system 2. System 1 is an automatic,
intuitive, and unconscious

thinking mode. It's fast, but it can be
error prone as a result. System 2 is a more slow,
controlled, analytical,

and deliberate thinking mode. It's reliable, but it requires
significantly more cognitive

effort. And research in psychology
and cognitive science has found that people
rely far more on system 1

than system 2 in their
day-to-day lives. So to quickly make decisions,
people apply heuristics.

For example, there's the
availability heuristic, where they use immediate
examples of something that come to mind, rather than
taking in the full picture.

And the things that
come to mind immediately are usually based on frequent
examples or recent examples

or vivid examples in your life. Another heuristic
that people apply

is imitate the
majority heuristic, where they go with choices that
are popular in their socially

proximal reference group. So, for example, when you're
ordering food on DoorDash,

how many times do you
look through all items on the menu versus selecting a
popular dish from a restaurant?

So we wanted to see what does
this look like for machine learning. How do you define
bounded rationality

for machine learning? Now this is where
I have an example notebook that you're
welcome to go to and try out

things on your own. I'll mention visuals that are
important from that notebook here in a second. But again, you're welcome
to play with that.

OK. So that notebook will take
you to an example of using the Titanic survival data set.

Very important
data set that tries to predict based
on passenger info whether someone survived
the Titanic or not.

So in the notebook, you'll
see the data set, the model, and an explanation
tool called SHAP.

And these are some SHAP
visuals that you can see in the notebook right here. So here's the
global explanation.

This is the ordering of features
that the model thinks globally across all data points is
important about Titanic

survival. Here's the relationship
between the sex and survival.

Here's the relationship
between age and survival. And this on the bottom right
is one single data point.

So this is one passenger's
information on the y-axis here. And you can see how each
of those information pieces

made an impact towards the
final prediction of survival for this passenger. Now I'm going to
ask you a question

that data scientists
often have to think about. What would make
this prediction go

from 1, which is this passenger
surviving, to 0, not surviving?

Very morbid example, I know. But we're going
to talk about how we can flip the prediction for
this bottom right passenger

from surviving to not surviving. I'll even give you some options. You could change the cabin
value from D35 to E67.

You could change the
fare from $52 to $10. You could change the age of
the passenger from 37 to 70,

or you could change the
sex from male to female. So which of these
changes or more than one

do you think would flip the
prediction for this passenger on the bottom right
to not surviving?

They currently
survived, but we're wanting them to not survive. So take a couple of minutes.

Feel free to throw
answers at me. I saw someone already say three,
changing the age from 37 to 70.

Feel free to
discuss if you want, and we can come back
in a second here. I'm running the code.

You're running the code? This is a very important
data science problem, I know.

So I want you to
really think about it.

All right, show of hands. How many of you think
1 is the answer?

All right, nobody for 1. How many of you think
changing the fair will flip this prediction?
Maybe a couple here and there. How many of you think it's 3? Wow, that's a majority.

And how many of
you think it's 4? A couple. OK. All right.

So like I said, we're
making this passenger not survive the Titanic.

So, unfortunately, for a lot of
you, only 1 and 2 are accurate.

So 1 is a little bit
hard to reason about, unless you really care about
the schematics of the Titanic.

And I've done in depth,
sort of deep dives into it. I don't know what cabin
is where in the ship.

So it's hard to reason
about that, right? But it is accurate. I did run it. 2 is a little bit easier
to reason about, right?

If you reduce the
fare, this passenger, potentially, is in a
lower class cabin, right?

And lower class
cabins were hit first. So you can reason about that. 3 is also very easy
to reason about.

You increase someone's age,
maybe makes it harder for them to get to the lifeboats. Again, I said this
example is morbid.

the age does not matter
because the passenger class, being first class,
was a mediating factor.

And then 4 is inaccurate,
because females survived the Titanic
more than males did.

So both 3 and 4 are
actually inaccurate. Now this exercise
that we just did here,

this type of applying your
heuristics to solve a problem, we figured that data scientists
do this all the time in the data

and machine learning and AI
use that they do in their jobs, right? So we wanted to see, to what
extent do data scientists pick

accurate answers,
or to what extent do these heuristics
and biases come to play and they pick
inaccurate answers?

So to make this entire setting
a little bit more formal, we have these axes
to propose quadrants

for bounded rationality. The axes are time
and cognitive effort because that's what has
been used in the past

to study bounded rationality
and decision making. Now, when you apply
deliberate reasoning,

like for those of you
who may be opened up the schematic of the Titanic to
figure out where the cabin was,

when you deliberately
think about something and spend time on
it, it's called maximizing your cognitive mode.

And we felt that in the
interpretability setting, given everything we know about overuse
of interpretability tools,

this would be the
control condition without any interpretability. Now, again, because of what
we know about interpretability

already, we felt
like the opposite where you don't spend a lot
of time and cognitive effort

in your decision making, the
satisficing cognitive mode would be where the visual
explanations that you just saw

would land, right? So these are the
visual explanations. Static visuals from
interpretability tools

would fall under that category. Now does the
cognitive mode where you have to make very
quick decisions--

but these are also very
critical decisions. So settings like
health care where you're really, as a
doctor, making decisions

about patient survival. So we call this the
survival cognitive mode. Luckily, data scientists rarely
operate in that quadrant, right?

They often have more
time with the data. So this wasn't one of the
conditions in our study. And then that's what I like to
call the optimizing cognitive

mode, where you're spending
a lot of time with a system and interacting with it
and engaging with it.

But it's not
cognitively effortful. You're enjoying spending
time with the system.

So one thing we
learned in HCI is to have that kind
of interaction.

You can make a system more
interactive, more fun to use, with different
kinds of features. So we hypothesized that if there
were interpretability tools that

weren't just static visuals but
had more interactive features, they would fall under that mode.

And there are
tools that do that. So here's an example of
Google's What-If Tool. So using Google's
What-If Tool, you

can bin, color, scatter plots
using different cohorts of data,

as you can see here. You can also look
at counterfactuals for a single data point.

So you can see what the
nearest counterfactual is. You can see partial
dependence plots

for the feature relationship
with the output. You can see how each
individual prediction was

made, what was important
towards that prediction, change these values
in real time, and get real-time predictions
with updated values

for data point. So there's a lot more
you can do with this tool than the static visuals
that we saw before.

And this is just under
the Datapoint Editor. There are other tabs for
performance and fairness metrics

or different types of
feature information that this interactive
tool allows. Now, it isn't that
the information that

forms the basis of
the decision making that we did with the static
tools has completely changed. The information is the same.

The visuals that they're
using, the three types, are still primarily the same. It's just that they've added
interactive elements on top.

So you can change
things more quickly, get a reactive feeling
with the system.

So we ran a pre-registered
controlled experiment. It was between subjects. It was with data scientists,
about 119 of them,

where we tested
their performance between these conditions
that I just described.

We had a control condition
and two conditions each for visual explanations,
the static outputs,

and the interactive tools. Why two? Because we were testing
a glass box model,

a glass box approach, and
then a post-hoc explainer for a black box model.

The setup was very similar
to the colab notebook that I shared with you all. They could access code.

They could write code. They could access any
visuals they wanted. And in parallel, there
was a Qualtrics setup.

Qualtrics is a server platform. So they answered
multiple choice questions

about the data and the
model on Qualtrics. We had also provided
hints throughout the study

because in running
a study, you have to be careful about not
making the task so cumbersome

that participants
can't solve it. So that was the
high-level setup.

Any questions before I
get into even more detail? Yes.

The control-- Yep. Can you just explain
a little bit more of what that
actually looks like? Is it just like they're just
going through like data sheets,

or what is that? It's just we give
them a notebook with just the data set loaded
and a machine learning model.
No interpretability. Any other questions?

Yes. [INAUDIBLE] know what
tools they have available. What's their experience?

Was there specific material? Yeah. So like I said, it
was just the data and the model in a notebook.

So they could write
their own code on top. We did give them links to
potential explanation outputs,

but we did not
give them the code. In the other notebooks,
those explanation outputs were embedded in the
notebook by us already.

The interpretability tools
were already embedded. In the control
condition, if they wanted those types
of outputs, then they

would have to go to the
links that we had shared, read the documentation,
write their own code,

and then get those outputs.  But that's a good
question that leads

into the results a little bit. All right. So to study bounded rationality,
to measure whether it was

happening, we had some proxies. There were process-level proxies
that we wanted to measure.

These were predictably
time and cognitive effort, which have been
all about the axes

that we had designed
to begin with. We also included the
number of hints people used during the study as a way of
measuring whether they were

applying bounded rationality. And then, of course,
there's the outcome. What happens as a result
of the application

of bounded rationality
in the setting? So these were things like the
accuracy of people's answers

about the data and the model
and then the types of answers they selected.

So in the exercise we did,
there were some options that were purely accurate. Some that were
plausible that we could

reason about but maybe
accurate or inaccurate. And then there were answers
that were purely inaccurate.

There was no plausible reason
for them to be accurate, right? So we had these categories of
options in our multiple choice

questions that we
also studied as part of the quantitatively
defining bounded rationality.

So to study our
continuous variables, we used one-way ANOVAs and
TukeyHSD as a post-hoc test

to study them quantitatively. And then for our
categorical variable, we used Chi-square
test of independence.

I'm going to mention three
of these in the results, just in the interest of time.

So let's look at the
time spent on task. Now as you can see here,
people in the control condition

spent far more time on the
task significantly more than any of the
interpretability conditions.

So just as a basic
thing, it seemed people in the
interpretability conditions

spending less than
five minutes on task were clearly applying some
way to make the task go faster

compared to a control condition
without any interpretability.

And I should have said it's five
times more time spent on task in the control condition.

Now, maybe somewhat as
a consequence of that, for accuracy, control
also had the best numbers.

People in the control condition
were at least 17% more accurate

than those in the
interpretability conditions. Interpretability tools, whether
they were static or interactive,
did not seem to help. Yes? What's chance accuracy? Chance?

Yeah. Everyone's doing-- most of the
conditions are doing below 50%. Yeah. It was-- we had five
conditions-- or five questions.
Five options each. So 20%. Yeah, yeah.

OK. And then, of course, if
you look at the residuals from our Chi-squared
test, they also

showed the significant
directionality of people in the
control condition picking accurate
answers, compared

to the other conditions
which leaned more towards the other
types of answers.

So overall, our results from
our experiment, just to mention

them in the context
of this quadrant that we started with,
we're pretty expected

for the satisficing conditions. The people who were using
these static visual tools were satisficing.

They were spending less
time, less cognitive effort. What was surprising was the
interactive tools conditions.

We had expected that people
would spend more time on task and maybe get to
more accurate answers

using these interactive tools. But in practice, this fell in
the surviving quadrant instead.

And I'll mention
my hypothesis why. So for the static
tools, we had thought

these make things look so
easy in the form of just these static visuals
that people end up applying their cognitive
heuristics instead.

For the interactive tools,
it was the opposite. They are so complicated. There are so many features.

So many toggles. So many interactive elements
all coming at you at once

that people applied
their own heuristics as a way of not doing this
cognitively burdensome task.

Instead, our control
condition seems to be more closer to optimally
effortful than we had expected.

And I think this is
because of the question you asked before where people
did want interpretable outputs,

and they would have had to read
documentation and write code to do it. And we provided them with just
the right amount of information

on which code to implement. We gave them the link to the
right thing that they could then

use to implement and have in
their notebook as an answer. So that's why we
feel it was maybe

closer to that optimal
effortful condition that we were hoping
interpretability would be.

So that's our hypothesis for
what's not working and why.

The bounded
rationality is at play. That current
interpretability tools don't really take it
into consideration,

don't really
account for the fact that people apply
heuristics and biases.

I want to do another
quick pause there, if anyone has any thoughts,
comments, questions.

[INAUDIBLE] in the
control setting when-- if the people did add
interpretability tools and which ones did
they attend to--

So it was different
in that we did not want to give them the same
tool as the other conditions,

because those were heavy-duty,
full feature interpretability tools that would have required
a significant amount of work

on their part. Instead, we gave them links to
codes about similar explainers.

So if you wanted to get
feature attributions like the global
explanation, here's an equivalent that
looks similar.

So s similar but
not the same tools. Yeah. How may approximate percentage
of people that were actually

implemented in those tools? Because you had a very
large standard deviation. Yeah, you're right. The standard deviation
is pretty large,

and that was one of
our concerns as well. So of the 22 people
in that condition,

I believe it was--
the number was 14, who actually wrote code for
the tools that we had linked.

But, in addition to that,
the other participants still wrote code. It was just not implementing
what we had linked them to.

So all the people
in that condition wrote some kind of code. [INAUDIBLE] is also be different
if participants had [INAUDIBLE]

a time constraint
or had enough time to work through these
tools [INAUDIBLE]??

So we do not have any time
constraint in the study. The only time constraint
was that it was a study.

So they were taking time
out of their daily practices to do the task. But what we were surprised
by was this inclination

to quickly find answers that
interpretability conditions were serving.

The people knew--
the people that were using [INAUDIBLE]
about these tools. So they knew how to work with
them, or they had to learn,

or you give them a tutorial
before using the tool? Good question. So we had people
with prior experience

in machine learning
and interpretability, in general, in the study. Not the specific tools,
but we did give them

a tutorial and information
about the tool before the study, before we started
measuring the time they were spending on things.

The reason I'm asking
that is because I think these people may have
trust the tool or the outputs

because they don't know
how it actually works. Right. So as far as we know--

well, I guess, we
didn't really get into-- since the conditions
were randomly assigned, we didn't really ask
about specific tools

that people had used before. But the only thing
we know going in is that they had some
machine-learning experience.

And then we gave all
of them the same kind of basic training on
how to use the tool.

So whatever inferences they
made about that training, about the tool,
through that training, there's going to be
variance that covered

in the number of responses. Yeah. I don't know what order people
were asking questions in.

So I'm going to go here. Sorry. I guess in a
similar vein, how do you think these
results would change if it were for a more
general audience or people

with less technical expertise? Yeah, that's a good question. And my expectation is
the interpretability

results will be worse, because
not everyone knows how to code. So in a control condition
without any interpretability,

having to do that
coding task might not be feasible for everyone. So people would
